She competed in the [[2013 UCI Road World Championships – Women's road race|2013 UCI women's road race]] in [[Florence]] but failed to finish.{{cite web|url=http://cycling.sportresult.com/results/cr/2013/WM/11RES00.pdf|title=Final Results / Résultats finaux: Road Race Women Elite / Course en ligne femmes élite|work=Sport Result|publisher=[[Tissot|Tissot Timing]]|date=28 September 2013|accessdate=28 September 2013|format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]}} Bertine was born in [[Bronxville, New York]].{{cite news|last1=Hager|first1=Collin|title=A Q & A with Kathryn Bertine, ESPN Olympian - Part I|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/43208-a-q-a-with-kathryn-bertine-espn-olympian-part-i|work=[[Bleacher Report]]|date=1 August 2008}} She was a [[figure skater]] until the age of 23, appearing in ice skating shows including the [[Ice Capades]] and [[Holiday on Ice]]. She undertook her undergraduate education at [[Colgate University]], where she competed in [[cross country running]] and [[rowing]] alongside skating. After graduating she took a year out to travel and pursue her skating career, before returning to education to study for a [[Master of Fine Arts]] degree at the [[University of Arizona]]. Whilst in Arizona she took up competing in [[triathlon]], eventually spending three years as a professional in the sport.{{cite web |url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1291292-road-to-the-olympics-kathryn-bertine-cyclist |title=Road to the Olympics: Kathryn Bertine, Cyclist |last1=Fan |first1=Pan Pan |date=9 August 2012 |website=[[Bleacher Report]]|accessdate=4 July 2014}} Bertine also pursued a career as a writer, working for [[ESPN]]. Whilst working at ESPN she accepted an assignment in 2006 to qualify for the [[2008 Summer Olympics]] in any sport, choosing to focus on cycling. She took up citizenship of Saint Kitts and Nevis alongside her American citizenship to be able to even attempt qualification for the Olympics. However she failed to qualify for the 2008 Games. Although her ESPN assignment was now over she attempted to qualify again for the [[2012 Summer Olympics]], again unsuccessfully. back to the Tour."{{cite web|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/27/sports/cycling/tour-de-france-2014-women-push-to-compete-in-cyclings-top-event.html|title=Women as Athletes, Not Accessories, at Least for a Day|date=27 July 2014|work=The New York Times|accessdate=9 April 2016}} She was signed by the [[Wiggle Honda]] team in 2014, ahead of the inaugural running of [[La Course by Le Tour de '''Katherine Karen Dunn''' (October 24, 1945 – May 11, 2016) was an American best-selling novelist, journalist, voice artist, radio personality, book reviewer, and poet from [[Portland, Oregon]].  She is best known for the novel ''[[Geek Love]]'' (1989).  She was also a prolific writer on [[boxing]].

==Early life==
Dunn was born in [[Garden City, Kansas]], in 1945.<ref name="CAO">"Katherine (Karen) Dunn." ''Contemporary Authors Online''. Detroit: Gale, 2005. ''Biography In Context''. Web. 5 Oct. 2013.</ref> She was the second-youngest of five siblings; her father left before she was two. Her mother, Velma Golly, an artist from North Dakota, married a mechanic<ref name="nyt">{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/15/books/katherine-dunn-author-of-geek-love-dies-at-70.html?_r=0 | title=Katherine Dunn, Author of ‘Geek Love,’ Dies at 70 | work=NY Times | date=14 May 2016 | accessdate=19 May 2016 | author=SAM ROBERTS}}</ref> or/and fisherman from the Pacific Northwest.<ref name=WW25>{{cite news
|title=Geek Loved
|first=Caitlin
|last=Roper
|date=April 2, 2014
|work=Willamette Week
|url=http://www.wweek.com/portland/article-22200-geek_loved.html
}}</ref> The family moved frequently during her childhood.<ref name=WW25 /> She went to high school in [[Tigard, Oregon]], and later attended [[Reed College]] in Portland, initially majoring in philosophy, then psychology.<ref name=WW25 />

==Career==
Dunn began her first novel, ''Attic'', while studying at Reed, and she left without graduating. At a Christmas break trip to Ashbury Heights in 1967 she met a man she would spend the next 10 years with. They traveled to Mexico, Boston, Newfoundland, and Seville, where she finished ''Attic'', then to [[Karpathos]], where she finished her second novel ''Truck'' (1971) and became pregnant.<ref name=WW25 /> She gave birth to her son in Dublin, Ireland, and after seven years living in various places, they returned to Portland to stay, "because there was a good alternative public school", the [[Metropolitan Learning Center (Portland, Oregon)]].<ref name=WW25 /> She settled in the Nob Hill neighborhood, where she lived until her death.<ref name="nyt" />

Dunn waited tables in the morning before her son woke up, and tended bars at night, painted houses, and did voice-over work. <ref name=WW25 />In the 1970s, she hosted a radio show on Portland's community radio station [[KBOO]], in which she would read short stories. She taught advanced classes in creative writing at Oregon's [[Lewis & Clark College]] and a graduate course in creative writing at [[Pacific University]] in Forest Grove, Oregon.{{cn|date=May 2016}}

In 1981, Dunn started writing about boxing in the ''Willamette Week'' She has been described as "one of the better boxing writers in the United States".<ref name=promise/> She started boxing training in her 40s.<ref name="nyt" /> 

She was an editor and contributor for the online boxing magazine cyberboxingzone.com. In the 1990s Dunn wrote a regular column on [[boxing]] for ''[[PDXS]]'' , in which she at one time provided detailed criticism of [[Evander Holyfield]]'s sportsmanship in his [[The Bite Fight|controversial fight]] with [[Mike Tyson]].<ref name="Dunn_1">Dunn, Katherine., [http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/box9-99.htm#kd Defending Tyson], ''[[PDXS]] via cyberboxingzone.com'', 1997-07-09, Retrieved on 2007-04-18.</ref> She won the [[Lange-Taylor Prize|Dorothea Lange—Paul Taylor Award]] in 2004 for her work on ''School of Hard Knocks: The Struggle for Survival in America’s Toughest Boxing Gyms''.<ref>[http://cds.aas.duke.edu/l-t/2004winners.html Announcement of 2004 prize winners]</ref>  Her essays on boxing were collected in the 2009 anthology ''One Ring Circus: Dispatches from the World of Boxing''.<ref>[http://www.schaffnerpress.com/books/detail/3/ Schaffner Press Website]</ref>
In 1989 Dunn's novel ''[[Geek Love]]'' was a finalist for the [[National Book Award]]. She described her memory of when she began writing it in the late '70s, walking to Portland's Washington Park Rose Garden, contemplating nature versus nurture and the genesis of the book with its publication in 1989.<ref name=WW25 />  

In 1989, Dunn announced that she was working on a fourth novel, entitled ''The Cut Man''.<ref>''The Guardian'', April 1989</ref> She was still living in Portland and working on the book in 1999.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://wweek.com/html/25-what.html |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20101223064536/http://wweek.com/html/25-what.html |archivedate=23 December 2010 |title=Whatever Happened To...? |last=Buckingham |first=Matt |date=10 November 1999 |work=[[Willamette Week]] |accessdate=2013-09-03}}</ref> In 2008, it was reported that publisher [[Alfred A Knopf|Alfred A. Knopf]] had scheduled ''The Cut Man'' for release in September.<ref name=promise>{{cite news
|title=But you promised!
|last=Starr
|first=Karla
|date=February 1, 2006
|work=Willamette Week
|url=http://wweek.com/editorial/3213/7205/
}}</ref> The novel was not published at that time, but an excerpt appeared in the summer 2010 issue of ''[[The Paris Review]]''<ref name=nytimes.>{{cite news|title=The Return of Katherine Dunn|last=Cowles|first=Gregory|date=June 11, 2010|work=New York Times Paper Cuts Blog|url=http://papercuts.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/06/11/the-return-of-katherine-dunn/}}</ref> under the title ''Rhonda Discovers Art''.<ref name=rhonda>{{cite news |title=Rhonda Discovers Art|last=Dunn|first=Katherine|year=2010|work=The Paris Review|url=http://www.theparisreview.org/viewmedia.php/prmMID/6016}}</ref>
In 2012 Dunn reunited with her boyfriend from Reed College, Paul Pomerantz, and they married.<ref name="nyt" />

Dunn died on May 11, 2016. Her son stated her death was due to complications of lung cancer.<ref>{{cite news | title=Katherine Dunn, Author of Geek Love, Dies at 70 | first=Nigel | last=Jaquiss | work=Willamette Week | date=May 12, 2016 | url=http://www.wweek.com/news/2016/05/12/katherine-dunn-author-of-geek-love-dies-at-70/ }}</ref><ref name=TribObit>{{cite news | title=Award-winning Portland writer Katherine Dunn dies at 70 | date=May 12, 2016 | work=Portland Tribune | url=http://portlandtribune.com/pt/9-news/306619-184653-award-winning-portland-writer-katherine-dunn-dies-at-70 }}</ref>

==Bibliography==
Dunn wrote the text for ''Death Scenes: A Homicide Detective's Scrapbook'' (1995), a book of homicide photography; the humorous ''The Slice: Information with an Attitude'' (1989), which contains her collected newspaper columns from the Portland weekly newspaper ''[[Willamette Week]]''; ''3 Day Fox: A Tattoo'', a poem; and numerous articles for ''[[Playboy]]'', [[Vogue magazine|''Vogue'']], and the [[Los Angeles Times|''L.A. Times'']].

*''Attic'' (1970)
*''Truck'' (1971)
*''[[Geek Love]]'' (1989)
*''Death Scenes: A Homicide Detective's Scrapbook'' (1996)
*''One Ring Circus: Dispatches from the World of Boxing'' (2009)

[[Golf course#Design|Golf course designer]] |residence = [[Carmel, Indiana]] |spouse = [[Pete Dye|Paul "Pete" Dye, Jr.]] |children = Perry & P.B. (Paul Burke) |parents = |religion = |awards= |}} '''Alice Dye''' (born 1927) is an American amateur [[golf]]er and [[golf course designer]] known as the "First Lady" of golf [[architecture]] in the United States. She was born as '''Alice Holliday O'Neal''' in [[Indianapolis, Indiana]] and began playing golf at a young age, winning eleven Indianapolis Women's City titles. She graduated from [[Shortridge High School]],{{cite web |title=Alice Dye biographical sketch |url=http://golfarchitects.lib.msu.edu/dyea/dyeabio.htm |publisher=American Society of Golf Course Architects |accessdate=May 31, 2012}} and in 1946 won the first of her nine Indiana Women's Golf Association Amateur Championships. While a student at [[Rollins College]] in [[Winter Park, Florida]], she was captain of the golf team. At college she met [[Pete Dye|Paul "Pete" Dye, Jr.]] following his discharge from [[World War II]] military service. She graduated in 1948 with a [[B.S.]] degree. In early 1950, she and Pete Dye were married. Their marriage produced two sons, Perry and P.B. (Paul Burke), as well as one of the top design teams of American golf courses, famous for their design of the [[TPC at Sawgrass]] (it was Alice who came up with the idea of the Island Green, the signature 17th hole at Sawgrass' Stadium Course). She became the first woman president of the [[American Society of Golf Course Architects]], and the first to serve as an independent director of [[Professional Golfers' Association of America]] (PGA). She won the 1968 [[North and South Women's Amateur]] and was a member of the 1970 United States [[Curtis Cup]] team. Dye won the 1978 and 1979 [[U.S. Senior Women's Amateur]] as well as two Canadian Women's Senior Championships. She has been a member of the [[USGA]] Women's Committee, the [[LPGA]] Advisory Council and a member of the Board of Directors of the Women's Western Amateur who honored her with their Woman of Distinction Award. She and her husband established a golf training program at [[Purdue University]]. Alice Dye was inducted into the Indiana Golf Hall of Fame in 1976 and in 2004 was voted the PGA's First Lady of Golf Award. She collaborated on the book "''From Birdies to Bunkers: Discover How Golf Can Bring Love, Humor and Success into Your Life''" with Mark Shaw that was published in 2004 with a [[Foreword]] by [[Nancy Lopez]]. '''Some of the golf courses designed by Alice Dye:''' * [[TPC at Sawgrass]] – [[Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida]] * [[Crooked Stick Golf Club]] – [[Indianapolis, Indiana]] * [[Whistling Straits]] – [[Kohler, Wisconsin]] * [[La Quinta Resort and Club|PGA West]] – [[Palm Springs, California|Palm Springs (La Quinta), California]] * [[Kiawah Island Golf Resort]] (Ocean Course) – [[Kiawah Island, South Carolina]] ==Tournament wins== *1968 [[North and South Women's Amateur]] *1978 [[U.S. Senior Women's Amateur]] *1979 [[U.S. Senior Women's Amateur]] *1983 Canadian Women's Senior Championship *1984 Canadian Women's Senior Championship ==Team appearances== '''Amateur''' *[[Curtis Cup]] (representing the United States): 1970 (winners) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://golfarchitects.lib.msu.edu/dyea/index.html ASGCA Architect's Gallery - Alice Dye entry] *[http://asgca.org/members/82?mid=54 American Society of Golf Course Architects profile] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dye, Alice}} [[Category:American female golfers]] [[Category:Amateur golfers]] [[Category:Rollins Tars women's golfers]] [[Category:Golf course architects]] [[Category:Golfers from Indiana]] [[Category:American women sportswriters]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Indianapolis, Indiana]] [[Category:People from Carmel, Indiana]] [[Category:1927 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Date of birth missing (living people)]]

'''Helene Elliott''' is an [[United States|American]] [[sportswriter]] for the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' who is a general sports columnist. She is the first female [[journalist]] to be inducted into the [[Hockey Hall of Fame]], receiving the [[Elmer Ferguson Memorial Award]] for bringing "honor to journalism and to hockey" in 2005.

One of the first women to cover the sport, Elliott began her career in the late 1970s when many [[locker room]]s and [[press box]]es were closed to women, except by court order. As such, she often had to wait for hours after games ended to conduct interviews. She has covered almost all major events in [[ice hockey]], including every [[Stanley Cup Final]]s since {{scfy|1980}}, the "[[Miracle on Ice]]" defeat of the [[Soviet Union]] national team by the U.S. team in the [[1980 Winter Olympics]], and the growth of hockey on the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]] fueled by [[Wayne Gretzky]]'s arrival to the [[Los Angeles Kings]].

She is married to author Dennis D'Agostino, a former publicist with the [[New York Mets]] and [[New York Knicks|Knicks]].

In 2006, after many years of covering hockey and Olympic sports, she became a general sports columnist.

'''Mary Ellen Garber''' (April 19, 1916 – September 21, 2008) was an [[United States|American]] [[Sports journalism|sportswriter]], who was a pioneer among [[Women in journalism and media professions|women sportswriters]]. She received over 40 writing awards and numerous honors in a sports-writing career that spanned seven decades, the most prestigious of which was the 2005 Associated Press Sports Editors (APSE) [[Red Smith Award]]. Garber, the first woman to win the APSE award, also became the first woman to be inducted into the U.S. Basketball Writers Hall of Fame in 2002.<ref>[http://www.wssportsmenclub.org/sportsmen_club_035.htm Winston-Salem Sportsmen's Club]</ref>

==Life and career==

She was born in [[New York City]] in 1916, but relocated to [[Winston-Salem]], [[North Carolina]], with her family in 1924. At the age of eight, she had two passions: journalism and sports. She not only read the sports page, she played football—tackle football—for the Buena Vista Devils. As she matured, her five-foot, ninety-pound frame limited her to [[softball]] and [[tennis]], but her love of sports never slackened. While other girls swooned over movie stars, Garber, a huge [[Knute Rockne]] fan, wrote letters to [[University of Notre Dame|Notre Dame]] football players.<ref>[http://wpcf.org/oralhistory/garb.html ''Women in Journalism''], The Washington Press Club Foundation Oral History Project.</ref>

Garber graduated from [[Hollins College]] in [[Virginia]], in 1938, with one goal: to become a newspaper reporter. In an interview with local historian Frank Tursi, Garber said, ''"I never considered anything else. But never at any time did I think about being a sportswriter"''.<ref>Tursi, Frank V. ''Winston-Salem Journal: Magnolia Trees and Pulitzer Prizes''. p. 98-100.</ref>

In 1940, the aspiring reporter entered journalism as the society editor at the ''[[Twin City Sentinel]]''. America's entry into [[World War II]] created a vacuum in the newspaper that enabled her to become a general assignment reporting. Later in 1944, when the high school sports stringer at the paper graduated and enlisted in the [[U.S. Navy]], Garber filled his slot. At the end of the war, she moved back to general assignment reporting but not for long. After a year of dogging sports editor Carlton Bryd for sports assignments, both Bryd and managing editor, Nady Cates, agreed: Garber belonged on the sports beat.

In 1946, Garber joined the sports department and never left. Two things distinguished her career. For 30 years, she was the only female sportswriter in the Winston-Salem ([[ACC Conference]]) region and one of the few in the country. Also, when she entered sports journalism in 1946, she started covering the two black high schools in the Winston-Salem/Forsyth County region, [[Atkins High School (North Carolina)|Atkins High School]] and [[Carver High School (Winston-Salem, North Carolina)|Carver High School]].<ref>[http://winstonsalem.nc.schoolwebpages.com/education/school/school.php?sectionid=131&sc_id=1180106164 Carver High School - Home<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

She also covered [[Winston-Salem State University]], a black university. Her appearance at those schools launched her as an advocate for black athletes and coaches in the segregated region. Prior to her, both Winston-Salem papers, the ''Twin Cities Sentinel'' and the ''Winston-Salem Journal'', used school correspondents to call in game results.<ref name=AWSM>[http://www.awsmonline.org/pioneer_about.html The Association of Women in Sports Media]</ref>

As a woman, Garber was not allowed into team locker rooms and so had to wait outside the door, hoping to get quotes from coaches and players. At North Carolina State games, a security guard named John Baker (Raleigh NC police officer) hauled athletes out of the lockers to make sure she got her quotes.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/03/sports/03vecsey.html?em&ex=1210046400&en=adbf7bf4c186feef&ei=5087%0A | work=The New York Times | title=An Overdue Honor for a Pioneer Sportswriter | first=George | last=Vecsey | date=May 3, 2008 | accessdate=May 12, 2010}}</ref>

When the ''[[Winston-Salem Journal]]'' acquired the ''Sentinel'' in the 1980s, Garber moved with it. She retired from the ''Journal'' in 1986, but continued working part-time until 2002. In 2006, the Association of Women in Sports Media (AWSM) renamed its ''Pioneer Award'' the ''Mary Garber Pioneer Award''.<ref name=AWSM />

In 1998, Garber received the [[Mel Greenberg Media Award]].<ref name="Mel Greenberg Media Award">{{cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Mel Greenberg Media Award|url=http://www.wbca.org/pages/AWARDS_mel-greenberg|work=|publisher=Women's Basketball Coaches Association|accessdate=2 Jul 2014}}</ref>

In May 2008, Garber was inducted into the Hall of Fame of the [[National Sportscasters and Sportswriters Association]].<ref name="vecsey2008">Vecsey, George (May 3, 2008). [http://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/03/sports/03vecsey.html An Overdue Honor for a Pioneer Sportswriter.] ''[[New York Times]]''</ref>

Garber recounted her life and career in a series of interviews for the [[Washington Press Club]] Foundation's ''Women in Journalism'' Oral History Project.<ref>[http://www.wpcf.org/oralhistory/garb.html Mary Garber Interview<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

A girls' high school basketball tournament, called the ''Mary Garber Holiday Tip-Off Classic'', is named in Garber's honor and has been held annually in Winston-Salem since 1989.<ref>[http://wssportsmenclub.org/sportsmen_club_034.htm Mary Garber<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Garber died in [[Winston-Salem, North Carolina]].<ref name="nytobit">Goldstein, Richard (September 22, 2008). [http://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/23/sports/23garber.html Mary Garber, Sportswriter, Dies at 92.] ''[[New York Times]]''</ref>

[[File:Christina Kahrl 2009.jpg|thumb|Kahrl in 2009.]]
'''Christina Kahrl''' (previously known as Chris Kahrl) is one of the co-founders of [[Baseball Prospectus]]. She is the former executive editor of the [[think tank]]'s website, BaseballProspectus.com,<ref>Kahrl, Christina. "Changing Teams," [http://www.baseballprospectus.com/unfiltered/?p=345 BaseballProspectus.com, April 26, 2007.]</ref> the former managing editor for their annual publication, and is currently writing and editing for [[ESPN|ESPN.com]]. She is a member of the [[Baseball Writers Association of America]].

Kahrl is an activist on civil rights issues for the [[transgender]] community in her hometown of [[Chicago, Illinois|Chicago]] and a member of the Equality Illinois board of directors.<ref>Dave McKenna, "Baseball Columnist Switches Gender, Keeps Career," [http://web.archive.org/web/20090415092347/http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/cheap/2005/cheap0826.html ''Washington City Paper'', August 26-September 1, 2005].</ref> The story of her publicly coming out as a transsexual sportswriter in 2003 was part of a [[Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation|GLAAD]]<ref>The GLAAD Awards: Outstanding TV Journalism - Newsmagazine [http://www.glaad.org/mediaawards/22/nominees GLAAD.org]</ref> award-nominated segment entitled "Transitions" on [[HBO]]'s [[Real Sports with Bryant Gumbel|Real Sports]] that aired in 2010.<ref>''Real Sports'' with Bryant Gumbel, Episode 156 Synopsis [http://www.hbo.com/real-sports-with-bryant-gumbel/episodes/0/156-march-16-2010/synopsis.html HBO.com]</ref>

==Background==
Kahrl graduated from [[El Camino Fundamental High School|El Camino High School]] in [[Sacramento]], [[California]] in 1985. She graduated from the [[University of Chicago]] in 1990, with a concentration in Modern European History and a minor concentration in Ancient History. She was a member of [[Phi Kappa Psi]] fraternity. In 2000 she earned an MA in Public History from [[Loyola University Chicago]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailyherald.com/story/?id=157428|title=Here's a baseball guidebook with more than predictions|publisher=[[Chicago Daily Herald]]|last=Cox|first=Ted|date=2008-03-20}}</ref> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Christina Kahrl at the Equality Illinois Gala, 12 February 2011.png|thumb|Christina Kahrl at the Equality Illinois Gala in February 2011.]] -->

==Career==
From 2000 to 2005, Kahrl was employed as an acquisitions editor at Brassey's Sports (US), a mid-list publisher that focused on sports history and analysis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://us.penguingroup.com/nf/Author/AuthorPage/0,,1000070131,00.html|title=Christina Kahrl - Penguin Books USA|publisher=|accessdate=22 July 2016}}</ref>

After the launch of BaseballProspectus.com in 1996, of which she was a founding member, she contributed a regular column entitled "Transaction Analysis," listing and analyzing the transactions (player trades, contract signings, promotions and demotions) by all [[Major League Baseball]] teams for the site. In 2011, she kicked off a new standalone opinion and argument column for the site entitled "Purpose Pitches."<ref>Kahrl, Christina. "Purpose Pitches" archive, [http://www.baseballprospectus.com/search/index.php?search_query=&search_author=&search_article=125&search_month_1=01&search_year_1=1996&search_month_2=12&search_year_2=2011&sort_by=date&search_max=0&submit=Search+Archives BaseballProspectus.com]</ref> She was a co-editor of nine of the ''Baseball Prospectus'' annual volumes of baseball statistics and analysis.<ref>For a list, see [[Baseball Prospectus]].</ref>

Kahrl has also written for [[SI.com|SportsIllustrated.com]], [[ESPN.com]], the ''[[New York Sun]]'', [[Salon.com]], ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', ''[[Playboy]]'', and the ''[[Washington Blade]]'', and was an associate editor of ''The ESPN Pro Football Encyclopedia.''

In 2008, Kahrl was accepted as a member of the [[Baseball Writers Association of America]] and thus became eligible to vote on [[Major League Baseball]] post-season awards and nominees for the [[National Baseball Hall of Fame]]. She voted for the [[American League]] Rookie of the Year in 2009<ref>Kahrl, Christina. "Voting for Real: AL Rookie of the Year," [http://www.baseballprospectus.com/article.php?articleid=9775 BaseballProspectus.com, 16 November 2009]</ref> and for the [[National League]] Manager of the Year in 2010.<ref>Kahrl, Christina. "Voting for Real: The NL Manager of the Year Award," [http://www.baseballprospectus.com/article.php?articleid=12468 BaseballProspectus.com, 18 November 2010]</ref> Reflecting on the meaning of her election, Kahrl wrote, "While I expect to still write about transactions, I really want to try and breathe new life back into the game story as an art form, and perhaps in my conceit try to take pages from [[Damon Runyon|Runyon]] and [[Ring Lardner|Lardner]] and [[Pete Palmer]] and [[Keith Woolner]] to provide something old and something new, all at once."<ref>[[King Kaufman]], "BBWAA Votes in Prospectus, Neyer, Law," [http://www.salon.com/sports/kaufman/feature/2008/12/11/baseball_writers/index.html ''[[Salon.com]]'', December 11, 2008].</ref>

In April 2011,<ref>Kahrl, Christina, "Purpose Pitches: A New Delivery," [http://www.baseballprospectus.com/article.php?articleid=13408 BaseballProspectus.com, 1 April 2011]</ref> Kahrl announced that she would be joining ESPN.com to write and edit, teaming up with David Schoenfield in penning the "SweetSpot" blog, which provides a [[sabermetrics]]-driven analysis on the goings-on in baseball.

In 2014 Kahrl was inducted into the [[Chicago Gay and Lesbian Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.glhalloffame.org/index.pl?page=inductees&todo=year|title=Chicago Gay and Lesbian Hall of Fame|publisher=|accessdate=22 July 2016}}</reF>

==Activism==
Since 2007, Kahrl has been active in the [[LGBT]] community, helping out with transgender programming at the [[Center on Halsted]],<ref>[http://www.centeronhalsted.org/coh/press/press.cfm?pressid=221 Center on Halsted].</ref> running the support group and adding a seminar series and an open mic night to its programming, as well as speaking about activist efforts in the area.<ref>[http://news.medill.northwestern.edu/chicago/news.aspx?id=148503 Medill News].</ref> She has spoken to local student groups and on college campuses about acceptance of transgender people in society and in sports, and on transgender issues. She is a member of the board of Illinois Gender Advocates (IGA), and co-chair of IGA's action committee.

As an activist and board member for [[Equality Illinois]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.equalityillinois.org/index.html |title=EqualityIllinois.org |publisher=EqualityIllinois.org |date= |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref> Kahrl has been actively involved in an effort to curb police harassment of transgender Chicagoans, and has helped launch the Trans-Friendly Bathroom Initiative<ref>The T-Friendly Bathroom Initiative,  [http://friendlybathrooms.wikkii.com/wiki/Main_Page T-Friendly Bathrooms Wiki]</ref> with fellow activists from Genderqueer Chicago.<ref>Barlow, Gary. "New initiative highlights T-friendly businesses, [http://www.nowingaychicago.com/2011/02/new-initiative-highlights-t-friendly.html Gay Chicago Magazine, 20 February 2011]</ref> She has also helped organize the public observation of [[Transgender Day of Remembrance]] in Chicago. She has also discussed the nature of transsexuality at the [[Chicago History Museum]], stating, "You have to explain to people that, no, this (being transsexual) does not mean that you are supergay, although it's sweet of you to say so. Forging acceptance in the face of inevitable confusion and concern is the diplomatic mission of a lifetime, for each and every transsexual."<ref>Kahrl, Christina. "Sexicon" speech text, [http://www.facebook.com/note.php?note_id=175568479152773 Facebook.com, 2 February 2011]</ref>  On November 8, 2013 it was announced that she had been named to [[GLAAD]]'s Board of Directors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.glaad.org/blog/meet-glaads-new-board-co-chairs |title=Meet GLAAD's new board co-chairs! |publisher=Glaad.org |date=2013-11-08 |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref>

'''Ann Killion''' is an American sports journalist and author. She has written for [[Sports Illustrated]], [[San Francisco Chronicle]], [[Comcast Sportsnet]], [[San Jose Mercury News]], and [[The Los Angeles Times]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Ann Killion|url=http://www.kcrw.com/people/ann-killion|publisher=KCRW|accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref> She is the co-author of two books with Olympic gold medalists: ''Throw Like a Girl: How to Dream Big & Believe in Yourself'' with [[Jennie Finch]] and ''Solo: A Memoir of Hope'' with [[Hope Solo]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Almond|first1=Elliott|title=Bay Area author Ann Killion discusses upcoming Hope Solo book|url=http://blogs.mercurynews.com/olympics/2012/07/26/bay-area-author-ann-killion-discusses-upcoming-hope-solo-book/|publisher=San Jose Mercury News|accessdate=14 January 2015|date=July 26, 2012}}</ref>

==Early life and education==
Killion was raised in [[Mill Valley, California]] and attended [[Tamalpais High School]] where she was the sports editor for the school newspaper.<ref name=marinmag_0115>{{cite web|last1=Hershon|first1=Marc|title=9 Questions for Ann Killion|url=http://www.marinmagazine.com/January-2015/9-Questions-for-Ann-Killion/|publisher=Marin Magazine|accessdate=14 January 2015|date=January 2015}}</ref>
She completed her college degree at [[UCLA]] and obtained her master's degree in journalism from [[Columbia University]].<ref>{{cite web|title=About Ann Killion|url=http://annkillion.com/about/|publisher=Ann Killion|accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref>

==Works==
* ''Throw Like a Girl: How to Dream Big & Believe in Yourself.'' By [[Jennie Finch]] and Ann Killion. Location: 2011.
* ''Solo: A Memoir of Hope.'' By [[Hope Solo]] and Ann Killion. Location: 2012.

{{for|the IRA volunteer|Jackie McMullan}} {{Infobox person | image = Jackie-macmullan-lipofsky.jpg | image_size = | name = Jackie MacMullan | caption = MacMullan (right) with [[Red Auerbach]] in 1995 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1960|10|07}} | birth_place = [[Manhasset, NY]], United States | death_date = | death_place = | education = [[University of New Hampshire]] | occupation = Sports columnist
Author
Television Personality | spouse = Michael Boyle | parents = | children = Aly, Doug | niece = Julia Titone nephew = Chris Titone }} '''Jackie "Mac" MacMullan''' (born October 7, 1960) is an American freelance newspaper [[sportswriter]] and [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] columnist for the sports website [[ESPN.com]]. She attended Westwood High School in Massachusetts, and is a graduate of the [[University of New Hampshire]], where she played Division I basketball for the Wildcats, MacMullan was a columnist and associate editor of the [[Boston Globe]] until she took a buyout from the paper in March 2008.{{cite web |url=http://shots.bostonsportsmedia.com/2008/04/jackie-mack-taking-latest-globe-buyout|title= Jackie Mack Taking Latest Globe Buyout |accessdate=2008-04-01 |work=bostonsportsmediawatch.com:Scott's Shots }} She began writing for the Globe in 1982.{{cite web |url= http://espn.go.com/eoe/macmullen_bio.html|title= Jackie MacMullan The Boston Globe Around The Horn Panelist |accessdate=2007-05-23 |work= ESPN.com:ESPN Original Entertainment }} From 1995 to 2000 she covered the NBA as a senior writer for [[Sports Illustrated]]. In 1999, MacMullan collaborated with [[Larry Bird]] on his autobiography ''Bird Watching: on Playing and Coaching the Game I Love''. She released ''Geno: In Pursuit of Perfection'' with [[Geno Auriemma]] in 2006, and wrote the New York Times best seller "When the Game Was Ours" with Magic Johnson and Larry Bird in 2009. In 2011 MacMullan collaborated with NBA superstar Shaquille O'Neal to write his autobiography entitled ''Shaq Uncut: My Story''. MacMullan has been a correspondent for several cable television networks including [[ESPN]], [[CNNSI]], and [[NESN]], as well as [[WHDH-TV]] in Boston. She is a regular panelist on the ESPN program ''[[Around the Horn]]''. She has also co-hosted episodes of the network's [[Pardon the Interruption]]. In response to MacMullan's departure from the Globe, she had this to say in an email to the blog site ''Boston Sports Media Watch'': {{cquote|''It’s just time for me. My kids are growing up too fast, and I don’t want to miss anything. I’ll still do some freelance work but I’m not planning on taking another full-time job right now. It would be counter-productive to why I’m doing this in the first place.''}} On May 12, 2010, Jackie MacMullan and longtime Cleveland Cavaliers radio play-by-play announcer [[Joe Tait]] received the [[Curt Gowdy Media Award]] from the [[Basketball Hall of Fame|Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame]].{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/sports/basketball/celtics/articles/2010/05/12/macmullan_is_named_gowdy_award_winner/|title=MacMullan is named Gowdy Award winner|last=Finn|first=Chad|date=12 May 2010|work=Boston.com|accessdate=14 May 2010}} The awards are presented annually to members of the print and electronic media who made a significant contribution to the game of basketball. MacMullan was the first woman to receive the honor in its 21-year history. On May 4, 2013, in an article for ESPN, MacMullan took a controversial stance among members of the Boston media when she suggested that the [[Boston Celtics]] should part ways with team captain [[Paul Pierce]].{{cite web|last=MacMullen|first=Jackie|title=It's hard, but it's time to say goodbye|url=http://espn.go.com/boston/nba/story/_/id/9241264/2013-nba-playoffs-paul-pierce-kevin-garnett-part-ways-boston-celtics?utm_source=twitterfeed&utm_medium=twitter|work=ESPN Boston|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=4 May 2013}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.boston.com/sports/columnists/macmullan/ Archive of MacMullan's column at the Boston Globe] {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=''Boston Globe'' Celtics beat writer | before= Peter May | years=1989-1995 (interim)| after= [[Michael Holley]] }} {{s-end}} {{Curt Gowdy Media Award}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:MacMullan, Jackie}} [[Category:American sportswriters]] [[Category:National Basketball Association broadcasters]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Westwood, Massachusetts]] [[Category:American newspaper reporters and correspondents]] [[Category:The Boston Globe people]] [[Category:University of New Hampshire alumni]] [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:American women sportswriters]] [[Category:People from Manhasset, New York]] {{US-sportswriter-stub}}

The Jump }} '''Rachel Michele Nichols''' (née '''Alexander''', born October 18, 1973) is an American [[sports journalist]] who is currently an [[ESPN]] [[television host]], sports reporter, and anchor. She currently hosts ''The Jump'' weekdays at 3:30pm ET on ESPN. Nichols also appears on NCAA Tournament broadcasts on [[CBS]], sometimes paired with [[Verne Lundquist]] and [[Bill Raftery]].{{cite news |title=Verne Lunquist and Bill Raftery: TV's sunshine boys |work=USA Today |url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/columnist/hiestand-tv/2013/03/28/ncaa-mens-tournament-basketball-bill-raftery-verne-lundquist-cbs-tnt-tbs-rachel-nichols-sean-mcmanus/2028917/ |accessdate=November 1, 2013 |first1=Michael |last1=Hiestand |date=March 28, 2013}} Nichols began hosting ''Unguarded with Rachel Nichols'' on CNN in October 2013. The program was changed from a regular series to occasional special in October 2014.{{cite news| url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2014/10/unguarded-with-rachel-nichols-air-as-specials-cnn-turner-shakeup | work=USA Today | title='Unguarded with Rachel Nichols' will only air as specials after Turner shakeup}} Sports Illustrated has called Nichols "the country's most impactful and prominent female sports journalist." {{cite news |title=The Case for ... Rachel Nichols |work=Sports Illustrated |url=http://www.si.com/vault/2014/10/13/106646996/the-case-for--rachel-nichols |accessdate=November 20, 2014}} She earned widespread praise for her tough questioning of NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell in the wake of the Ray Rice scandal {{cite news |title=Rachel Nichols refused to let Roger Goodell off the hook |work=USA Today |url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2014/09/rachel-nichols-roger-goodell-nfl-press-conference |accessdate=November 20, 2014}} and for confronting boxer Floyd Mayweather on his history of domestic violence.{{cite news |title=CNN’s Rachel Nichols Confronts Floyd Mayweather over Domestic Abuse Charges |work=Mediaite |url=http://www.mediaite.com/tv/cnns-rachel-nichols-confronts-floyd-mayweather-over-domestic-abuse-charges/ |accessdate=November 20, 2014}} Nichols previously worked for [[ESPN]] and was a regular part of ''[[SportsCenter]]'',{{cite news| url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/2013/01/24/espn-rachel-nichols-cnn/1862515/ | work=USA Today | first1=Michael | last1=Hiestand | title=Rachel Nichols leaving ESPN for CNN | date=January 24, 2013}} ''[[Sunday NFL Countdown]]'' and ''[[Monday Night Countdown]]'', as well as a regular on the network's [[NFL]] and [[NBA]] coverage. Nichols was also a correspondent for ''[[E:60]]''{{cite web |title=Rachel Nichols: Reporter and E:60 Correspondent |url=http://www.espnmediazone3.com/us/2010/03/07/nichols_rachel/ |work=MediaZone (biography) |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date= March 7, 2010 |accessdate=May 31, 2011}} and worked as the sideline reporter on a number of ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' broadcasts.{{cite news |title=Anchors and Reporters: Rachel Nichols |work=CNN |url=http://www.cnn.com/CNN/anchors_reporters/nichols.rachel.html |accessdate=November 1, 2013}} Prior to her time at ESPN she worked for the ''[[Fort Lauderdale Sun-Sentinel]]'' (1995–1996) and ''[[Washington Post]]'' (1996–2004), where she covered the [[NHL]]'s [[Washington Capitals]].{{cite news |title=Rachel Alexander |work=The Washington Post |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/sports/longterm/talk/alexndr/rabio.htm |accessdate=June 15, 2008}} She also became a recurring guest on the "Pardon My Take" podcast (2016-present). ==Personal== Nichols was born Rachel Michele Alexander. She is a 1991 graduate of [[Winston Churchill High School (Potomac, Maryland)|Winston Churchill High School]] in Potomac, Maryland{{cite web|title=Rachel Nichols: WCHS '91 alumni|url=http://www.schoolspopular.com/MD/Potomac/Winston+Churchill+High+School.htm|accessdate=June 28, 2012}} and graduated from the [[Medill School of Journalism]] at [[Northwestern University]] '''Suziann Reid''' (born January 14, 1977) is an American-Jamaican former [[track and field]] [[sprint (running)|sprint]]er who specialized in the [[400-meter dash]]. She set a personal record of 50.74 seconds for the distance in 1999. She was a silver medalist with the American women's [[4 × 400-meter relay]] team at the [[1999 World Championships in Athletics]]. She was part of the World Championship team twice more, in 2001 and 2005, and helped the United States to silver at the [[2002 IAAF World Cup]] and gold at the [[2001 Goodwill Games]].

Reid competed collegiately for the [[Texas Longhorns]] and won three outdoor NCAA titles in the 400 m and two indoor NCAA titles. She also won four back-to-back NCAA outdoor titles in the 4 × 400 m relay. After her track career she became a writer and released ''Dark Secrets: Choosing Your Child's Sports Coach'' in 2013.<ref name=Kirk/>

==Career==

===Early life and college===
Born in [[Kingston, Jamaica]] with dual American citizenship, she moved the United States at age eleven and began attending [[Eleanor Roosevelt High School (Maryland)|Eleanor Roosevelt High School]] in [[Maryland]]. Her mother had been a track and field athlete in her youth. Reid took up [[cross country running]] at high school at age 14 and the coach suggested she try out for the indoor track team. It was a highly successful transition as she won a [[400-meter dash]] and [[800-meter run]] double at the Maryland state high school championship in 1992 then went on to take three consecutive sprint sweeps in the [[100-meter dash]], [[200-meter dash]] and 400-meter dash from 1993 to 1995. At national level, she won 400 m at the [[National Scholastic Indoor Championships]] in 1994 and 1995. By the time she finished her high school career she had a best of 52.77 seconds for the 400 m.<ref name=USATF>[http://www.usatf.org/athletes/bios/TrackAndFieldArchive/2005/Reid_Suziann.asp Suziann Reid]. USATF. Retrieved on 2016-08-24.</ref>

Reid gained a sports scholarship to attend the [[The University of Texas at Austin]] and began competing for their [[Texas Longhorns]] collegiate track team. In her first major competition she took third individually and in the [[4 × 400-meter relay]] at the 1996 [[NCAA Women's Division I Indoor Track and Field Championships]]. Success followed at the [[NCAA Women's Division I Outdoor Track and Field Championships|NCAA Outdoor Championships]] where she was 400 m champion and helped set a collegiate record of 3:27.50 minutes to win the relay. Having gained eligibility to represent the United States, she won the American junior title in 400 m and won the silver medal behind [[Andrea Burlacu]] at the [[1996 World Junior Championships in Athletics]].<ref name=USATF/>

At the 1997 NCAA Indoors she was off the podium in the 400 m but improved to runner-up in the relay. She achieved a personal record of 50.95 seconds in the NCAA Outdoor Championships final,<ref name=USATF/> edged out by [[LaTarsha Stroman]]. She retained the relay title for the Texas Longhorns that year. In her last two years of college competition she went undefeated with back-to-back wins in the 400 m indoors and outdoors at the NCAA meet.<ref>[http://www.gbrathletics.com/nc/ncaai.htm NCAA DIVISION I INDOOR CHAMPIONSHIPS]. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2016-08-24.</ref> She also helped the Longhorns to four straight NCAA 4 × 400 m relay titles from 1996 to 1999.<ref>[http://www.gbrathletics.com/nc/ncaaw.htm NCAA DIVISION I CHAMPIONSHIPS (WOMEN)]. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2016-08-24.</ref>

For her collegiate career, she was given the [[Honda Sports Award]] as the female track and field athlete of the year in 1999.<ref name=Kirk>[https://www.kirkusreviews.com/author/suziann-reid/ Suziann Reid]. Kirkus Reviews. Retrieved on 2016-08-24.</ref>

===Professional career===
Reid was a frequent competitor for the United States in 4 × 400-meter relay team and her first medal with them came at the [[1999 Summer Universiade]], where she anchored a team of [[Yolanda Brown-Moore]], [[Yulanda Nelson]] and [[Mikele Barber]] to the gold medals.<ref>[http://www.alltime-athletics.com/w4x400ok.htm All-time Women's best 4x400m relay]. Alltime Athletics. Retrieved on 2016-08-24.</ref> She was the 400 m runner-up at the [[1999 USA Outdoor Track and Field Championships]] to [[Maicel Malone]] and as result gained an individual and relay spot on the team for the [[1999 World Championships in Athletics]] She was eliminated in the semi-finals of the 400 m, but won a silver medal  leading off the relay team including [[Michelle Collins (athlete)|Michelle Collins]] and [[Jearl Miles Clark]], which finished behind Russia. Reid's career best run of 50.74 seconds that year ranked her third in the United States.<ref name=USATF/>

In the 2000 track season she won her first national title at the [[USA Indoor Track and Field Championships]], bringing an end to Jearl Miles Clark's three-year streak.<ref>[http://www.gbrathletics.com/nc/usawi.htm United States Indoor Championships (Women)]. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2016-08-24.</ref> She failed to make the Olympic team after missing the final at the [[2000 United States Olympic Trials (track and field)|2000 United States Olympic Trials]].<ref name=USATF/> She repeated as USA Indoor champion and ran at the [[2001 IAAF World Indoor Championships]], though an injury during her run in the final saw her finish a distant sixth. With a fifth-place finish at the [[2001 USA Outdoor Track and Field Championships]] she made the United States relay team. Reid did not another medal at the [[2001 World Championships in Athletics]] as she dropped the baton on the final exchange and the team of Miles-Clark, [[Monique Hennagan]] and Collins ended in fourth as a result. Redemption came at the [[2001 Goodwill Games]], where she anchored the same team to a gold medal in 3:24.63 minutes.

In the last few years of her career, Reid remained a finalist at national level and made two last international appearances in the relay. A team of Collins, [[Crystal Cox]], Reid and Hennagan claimed the silver medals behind the Americas team at the [[2002 IAAF World Cup]]. At the [[2005 World Championships in Athletics]], Reid led off the American women, but a line violation in the heats stage saw them disqualified. She retired after that competition.<ref name=USATF/>

'''Alanna Rizzo''' is a sports reporter with the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] broadcast team on [[SportsNet LA]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/dodgersnow/la-sp-dn-dodgers-hire-orel-hershiser-20131208,0,121849.story#axzz2mv3poBAI|title=Dodgers hire Orel Hershiser as new team broadcaster|first=Steve|last=Dilbeck|date=December 8, 2013|accessdate=December 8, 2013|work=Los Angeles Times}}</ref>

==Biography==
Rizzo is a native of [[Colorado]]. She participated in track and cross country at Sierra High School (class of 1993) in Colorado Springs, where she was later inducted into the athletic hall of fame.<ref name=Dream>{{cite web|last1=Rhodes|first1=Bethany|title=Sports-lover's dream job|url=http://gazette.com/sports-lovers-dream-job/article/700785|publisher=[[The Gazette (Colorado Springs)|The Gazette]]|accessdate=April 17, 2015|date=April 20, 2008}}</ref> Though she earned an undergraduate degree in international business, Rizzo's interests shifted away from the business world. She returned to the [[University of Colorado at Boulder]], where she received an M.A. in [[broadcast journalism]] in 2003.<ref name=DP>{{cite web|last1=Saunders|first1=Dusty|title=Rizzo makes smooth transition to TV|url=http://www.denverpost.com/sports/ci_12920009|publisher=[[Denver Post]]|accessdate=April 18, 2015|date=July 27, 2009}}</ref>

After stints as a sports anchor for CBS stations in [[Wichita Falls, Texas]], and [[Madison, Wisconsin]], Rizzo became a reporter for [[Root Sports Rocky Mountain]].<ref name=Dream/> She won three Regional Emmy awards. She worked at [[MLB Network]] from early 2012 until late 2013. She reported for the shows ''[[Intentional Talk]]'' and ''[[Quick Pitch (TV series)|Quick Pitch]]'' on [[MLB Network]].<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/network/personalities/?id=27274064 |title=Alanna Rizzo | MLB Network: On-Air Personalities |publisher=Mlb.mlb.com |date=2012-05-25 |accessdate=2012-06-16}}</ref>

She is married to hotel executive Justin Kole.<ref name=DP/> In 2012, Rizzo tweeted, "I have gotten this question 1,000 times. Although I have 3 relatives named Anthony Rizzo, I'm NOT related to the @Cubs [[Anthony Rizzo]]."<ref name=Twitter>{{cite web|title=Twitter page: Alanna Rizzo|url=https://twitter.com/alannarizzo/status/230141538037026816|publisher=[[Twitter]]|accessdate=April 17, 2015|date=July 30, 2012}}</ref>

{{BLP IMDb refimprove|date=October 2009}} {{Infobox person | name = Nell Scovell | birth_name = Helen Vivian Scovell | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Newton, Massachusetts]] | alma_mater = [[Harvard University]] | occupation = Journalist, writer, producer, director | spouse = Thomas Jonah Tisch (divorced)
Colin Summers | children = 2 }} '''Nell Scovell''' is a [[television]] and [[magazine]] [[screenwriter|writer]], [[television producer|producer]] and [[television director|director]]. She is the creator of the television series ''[[Sabrina, the Teenage Witch (TV series)|Sabrina, the Teenage Witch]]'', which aired on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] and [[The WB Television Network|The WB]] from 1996 until 2003. ==Early life and education== Nell Scovell, the middle of five children, grew up outside of [[Newton, Massachusetts]].{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/thecut/2013/12/long-strange-journey-of-nell-scovell.html |title=From Vanity Fair to Letterman to Lean In: The Long, Strange Journey of Nell Scovell |publisher=''New York Magazine'' |date=December 4, 2013 |first=Laura |last=Bennett |accessdate=October 8, 2014 }}{{cite web|url= |title=Nell Scovell '82 |publisher=Harvardwood |date=November 2013 |first=D. Dona |last=Le |accessdate=October 8, 2014 }} Her father, Melvin E. Scovell, is chairman of the board of [[Scovell & Schwager]], a health-care management company in Boston. In high school at [[Newton South High School]], she was the manager of the boys' track team. Scovell attended [[Harvard University]], where she spent her time reporting and editing sports stories for ''[[The Harvard Crimson]]''. In her senior year at Harvard, she wrote for the sports desk of the ''[[Boston Globe]]''. She graduated ''[[cum laude]]'' from [[Harvard University]] in 1982. ==Career== After graduation, she moved to New York and was the first staff writer hired by ''[[Spy (magazine)|Spy]]'' magazine in 1986. [[Tina Brown]] recruited her to work at ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'', contributing quirky visual features about money and culture. Scovell wrote a spec script for ''[[It's Garry Shandling's Show]]'', which they bought, and after serving as story editor for the final season of Newhart, she worked for [[David Letterman]]. As a television writer, Scovell wrote the season two episode of ''[[The Simpsons]]'', "[[One Fish, Two Fish, Blowfish, Blue Fish]]". Other TV writing credits include ''[[The Wilton North Report]]'', ''[[Coach (TV series)|Coach]]'', ''[[Monk (TV series)|Monk]]'', ''[[Murphy Brown]]'', ''[[Charmed]]'', ''[[Newhart]]'', ''[[The Critic]]'', ''[[NCIS (TV series)|NCIS]]'', and many others. She also wrote the season two episode of ''[[Space Ghost Coast to Coast]]'', "Urges". Outside of television, Scovell was the first staff writer hired at ''[[Spy (magazine)|Spy]]'' magazine and is a former contributing editor at ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]''. She has also written for ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'', ''[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]'', ''[[Self (magazine)|Self]]'', ''[[Tatler (1901)|Tatler]]'', and ''[[The New York Times Magazine]]''. She currently [[blog]]s for ''Vanity Fair'''s web site. Scovell has also directed two [[Television film|made for television movies]]: ''Hayley Wagner, Star'' for [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] and ''It Was One of Us'' for [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]]. ==Personal life== Scovell married Thomas Jonah Tisch, whose father is [[Laurence Tisch]], on June 16, 1985. This was her second marriage.{{cite web|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1985/06/17/style/nell-scovell-writer-marries-thomas-jonah-tisch.html |title=Nell Scovell, Writer, Marries Thomas Jonah Tisch |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=June 17, 1985 |accessdate=October 8, 2014 }} She is currently married to Colin Summers and has two children. Comedian/magician [[Penn Jillette]] called her "one of the funniest people alive" in an interview with ''[[The A.V. Club]]''.{{cite journal|title= Interview, Penn and Teller Part 2|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/penn-and-teller-part-2,13525/}} Scovell co-wrote [[Sheryl Sandberg]]'s 2013 book ''Lean In''.{{cite journal|title= Sheryl Sandberg's 'Lean In' offers a feminist view from the top|url=http://www.latimes.com/features/books/jacketcopy/la-ca-jc-sheryl-sandberg-20130310,0,818617.story}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|0780051}} *{{twitter|NellSco}} *[http://splitsider.com/2012/12/inside-the-greatest-writers-room-youve-never-heard-of/ Inside the Greatest Writers Room You've Never Heard Of] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Scovell, Nell}} [[Category:American film directors]] [[Category:American television directors]] [[Category:American television producers]] [[Category:American television writers]] [[Category:American women film directors]] [[Category:Women television directors]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Women television writers]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Showrunners]] [[Category:The Harvard Crimson people]] [[Category:Writers from Massachusetts]] [[Category:The Boston Globe people]] [[Category:American women sportswriters]] [[Category:Vanity Fair (magazine) people]] {{Simpsons-stub}}

'''Anne Ursu''' is an American novelist and children's writer based in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]].

Her first novels were for adults. ''Spilling Clarence,'' 2003, was about a small town suddenly afflicted with a flood of memory. ''The Disapparition of James,'' 2004, concerned the effect on his family of the disappearance of a small boy during a stage magic trick.

''Breadcrumbs,'' a middle-grade novel published by Walden Pond Press, was released September 27, 2011. Inspired by Hans Christian Andersen's "[[The Snow Queen]]," ''Breadcrumbs'' is a story of the struggle to hold on, and of the things we leave behind.

Ursu has also written a trilogy for middle-grade readers, the Cronus Chronicles, (published by [[Atheneum Publishers|Atheneum]]), involving two cousins' adventures in the realms of [[Greek mythology]].   The individual titles are ''The Shadow Thieves,'' ''The Siren Song,'' and  ''The Immortal Fire.''

She published another middle-grade fantasy in 2013, ''The Real Boy,'' which was longlisted for the National Book Award.

'''Lesley Candace Visser''' (born September 11, 1953) is an [[United States of America|American]] [[sportscaster]], television and [[radio personality]], and [[sportswriter]]. Visser is the first female NFL analyst on TV,<ref>http://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/2009-09-02-teams-values_N.htm</ref> and the only sportscaster in history (male or female) who has worked on [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|Final Four]], [[NBA Finals]], [[World Series]], [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|Triple Crown]], [[Monday Night Football]], the [[Olympics]], the [[Super Bowl]], the [[World Figure Skating Championships]] and the [[U.S. Open (tennis)|U.S. Open]] network broadcasts.  Visser, who was voted the No. 1 Female Sportscaster of all-time in a poll taken by the [[American Sportscasters Association]],<ref>http://blogs.tampabay.com/twocents/2009/07/two-centsbest-female-broadcasters.html</ref> She was elected to the [[National Sportscasters and Sportswriters Association]]'s [[NSSA Hall of Fame|Hall of Fame]] in 2015.<ref>http://www.nssafame.com</ref>

Visser recently became the first female to be an analyst for an NFL game on TV. She is currently a reporter for [[CBS Sports]] and [[CBS News|News]], writes for [[CBSSports.com]] and is also part of [[WFTL]] 640 Fox Sports' morning drive in [[South Florida]], as well as one of the hosts of a [[CBS Sports Network]] weekly television show, ''We Need to Talk''.

Visser <ref>http://www.cbssports.com/cbssports/team/lvisser</ref> was the first woman to be recognized by the [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]] as the 2006 recipient of the [[Pete Rozelle Radio-Television Award]] which recognizes long-time exceptional contributions to [[radio]] and [[television]] in professional football. Pro Football Hall of Famer [[Troy Aikman]] said about Visser in his 2006 induction speech, "She brought respect and professionalism to the field of journalism for her work in print and broadcasting. It makes me proud to be in her company today."

A pioneer among woman sports journalists, Visser re-joined [[CBS Sports]] in August 2000 after a six-year hiatus.  She was formerly the sideline reporter for ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' among other assignments she had at [[ESPN]] and [[ESPN on ABC|ABC Sports]], such as the World Series, the Triple Crown and the World Figure Skating Championship. She serves as correspondent for the network's [[NFL on CBS|NFL]] and [[College Basketball on CBS|college basketball]] programming.

==Early life==
Born on September 11, 1953, in [[Quincy, Massachusetts]],<ref>http://www.shemadeit.org/meet/biography.aspx?m=105</ref> to a school teacher and engineer, Visser loved sports from an early age. On Halloween, when other little girls would dress up as Mary Poppins, she would go as former [[Boston Celtics]] guard [[Sam Jones (basketball)|Sam Jones]]. From the age of 10 she wanted to be a sportswriter, but there was one problem—the job didn’t exist for women. Her family didn't discourage her. “My parents didn’t say girls can’t do that, and my mother told me, ‘Sometimes you have to cross when it says “don’t walk.”’” Visser was educated at [[Boston College]], majoring in English.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediabistro.com/articles/details.asp?aID=10770& |title=SO WHAT DO YOU DO, LESLEY VISSER, CBS SPORTS REPORTER AND HALL OF FAME SPORTSCASTER? |publisher=Mediabistro.com |date=January 27, 2010 |first=Brian T. |last=Horowitz |accessdate=November 21, 2014 }}</ref>

==Career==

===Boston Globe===
In 1974, Visser won a prestigious [[Carnegie Corporation of New York|Carnegie Foundation]] grant which entitled her to work as a [[sportswriter]] at ''[[The Boston Globe]]''. In 14 years at the ''Globe'', she covered [[college basketball]], the [[National Basketball Association|NBA]], [[Major League Baseball]], [[tennis]], [[college football]], [[golf]] and [[horse racing]]. In 1976, she was assigned to cover the [[New England Patriots]], becoming the first ever female NFL beat writer. In 2009, ''Sports Illustrated'' named ''The Boston Globe'' sports sections (1975–1980) the best sports section of all time. She is most well known for misreporting Michael Bowie's name in the infamous Boston College point shaving scandal.

===Begins television career at CBS Sports===
In 1983, she did a few features for [[CBS]]. In 1984, Visser joined CBS Sports part-time and went full-time in 1987. Her assignments included the [[NBA on CBS|NBA]] including the [[NBA Finals]], [[College Basketball on CBS|college basketball]] including the ''[[Final Four]]'', [[Major League Baseball on CBS|MLB]] including the [[World Series]], [[College World Series on CBS|College World Series]],<ref>http://www.lordly.com/index.php?option=com_speakers&task=view&contact_id=424&Itemid=47</ref> [[SEC on CBS|college football]], [[horse racing]], [[Tennis]] including the [[U.S. Open (tennis)|U.S. Open]] of Tennis (1984–1993) and the [[Olympics on CBS|Olympics]].

In 1989 she covered the fall of the [[Berlin Wall]], focusing on how sports would change in East Germany. In [[1990 NFL season|1990]] she became a regular on ''[[The NFL Today]]'' with [[Greg Gumbel]], [[Terry Bradshaw]] and [[Pat O'Brien (television)|Pat O'Brien]]. Also in [[1990 Major League Baseball season|1990]], Visser became the first woman to cover the [[1990 World Series|World Series]]. In [[Super Bowl XXVI|1992]], she became the first and only woman to handle the [[Vince Lombardi Trophy|Super Bowl Trophy]] presentation.

===ABC Sports and ESPN===
After [[CBS]] lost television rights to NFL games in 1993, Visser went to [[ABC Sports]] and [[ESPN]]. In 1995, she became the first woman ever to report from the sidelines during a Super Bowl when she covered [[Super Bowl XXIX]] for ABC. In 1998, she became the first woman ever assigned to ''[[Monday Night Football]]''. She also covered [[Super Bowl XXXIV]] for ABC in 2000.

While at ABC Sports, Visser served as a reporter for [[College Football on ABC|college football]] bowl games and the [[NFL playoffs]] games during ''Wild Card Saturday''. She also contributed to [[horse racing]] including the [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|Triple Crown]], ''[[ABC's Wide World of Sports]]'', [[Major League Baseball on ABC|Major League Baseball]], including the [[1995 World Series]], [[figure skating]], [[Special Olympics]], [[skiing]], the [[Pro Bowl]], and an ABC series ''A Passion to Play''. She co-hosted the network's coverage of the "[[Millennium]] [[Tournament of Roses Parade]]."

For ESPN, Visser covered the Super Bowl, [[College Basketball on ESPN|college basketball]], [[figure skating]], and [[Thoroughbred Racing on ESPN|horse racing]] including the [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|Triple Crown]].<ref>http://nacda.cstv.com/convention/proceedings/1999/scholarship.html</ref> She also contributed to ''[[SportsCenter]]'', ''[[NFL Countdown|NFL GameDay]]'', and ''[[Monday Night Countdown]]''.

===Return to CBS Sports===
In August 2000, Visser returned to [[CBS Sports|CBS]], with her assignments being [[NFL on CBS|NFL]], [[College Basketball on CBS|college basketball]], [[Tennis]], [[Figure Skating]] and [[Horse Racing]] as well as special projects for [[CBS News]]. Today Visser's assignments are a contributor to ''[[The NFL Today]]'' and [[College Basketball on CBS|college basketball]]. In 2004, she became the first woman sportscaster to carry the [[Olympic Torch]] when she was honored in 2004 by the International Olympic Committee as a "pioneer and standard-bearer."

During the [[2001 NFL season]] Visser became the first female color analyst <ref>http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_2001_June_26/ai_75894031</ref> ([[NFL on NBC|NBC]]'s [[Gayle Sierens]] was the first female play-by-play announcer) on an NFL broadcast booth. She joined play-by-play announcer [[Howard David]] and analyst [[Boomer Esiason]] in the booth for [[NFL on Westwood One|Westwood One]]/[[CBS Radio]]. Visser also joined [[HBO]]'s highly acclaimed ''[[Real Sports with Bryant Gumbel]]''.

Visser was a pre-game reporter for ''The Super Bowl Today'', where she covered the [[Super Bowl XXXV]] in February 2001, [[Super Bowl XXXVIII]] in February 2004, and the [[Super Bowl XLI]] in February 2007 pre-game broadcasts and during that 2007 Super Bowl she did serve as a sideline reporter too. Visser did contribute to the pre-game broadcast of the [[2010 Super Bowl]] as well as the [[2013 Super Bowl]]. Visser was loaned to [[NBC Sports]] twice to cover the Olympics as she covered the [[2004 Summer Olympics]] in Athens when she served as the Equestrian reporter. She also covered the [[2006 Winter Olympics]] in Torino as a reporter for Short Track Speed Skating.

In September 2007, she returned to roots as she now writes a column for [[CBSSports.com]].

==Personal life==
Visser was married from 1983 to 2010 to sportscaster [[Dick Stockton]], who broadcasts [[NFL on Fox|football]] and [[Major League Baseball on Fox|baseball]] for [[Fox Sports (USA)|Fox]] and [[Major League Baseball on TBS|baseball]] and the [[NBA on TNT|NBA]] for [[Turner Sports]]. Visser and Stockton met at the sixth game of the [[1975 World Series]], where Stockton called [[Carlton Fisk]]'s iconic home run for [[Major League Baseball on NBC|NBC]] and Visser was covering the game for ''[[The Boston Globe]]''.

Visser has been married since July, 2011 to businessman and former Harvard basketball captain Bob Kanuth.[http://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/24/fashion/weddings/lesley-visser-robert-kanuth-weddings.html]

In June 1993, Visser suffered a jogging accident in [[New York city|New York]]'s [[Central Park]] in which she broke her hip and skidded face-first across the pavement.<ref>http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0CE0DC123BF936A15754C0A965958260&n=Top%2fReference%2fTimes%20Topics%2fSubjects%2fJ%2fJogging SPORTS PEOPLE: BROADCASTING; A Recuperating Visser Aims for N.F.L. Opener – New York Times</ref> She required surgery on her face and hip and in 2006 she required an artificial hip replacement.

==Achievements==

===Events===
Visser has covered a number of events:
*34 [[Final Four]]s
*12 [[NBA Finals]]
*7 [[World Series]]
*15 [[Kentucky Derby]]s
*7 [[Preakness Stakes]]
*10 [[Belmont Stakes]]
*3 [[Summer Olympics]]
*3 [[Winter Olympics]]
*28 [[Super Bowl]]s
*7 [[World Figure Skating Championship]]s
*29 [[US Open (tennis)]]
*15 [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]]s

===Honors===
In June 2006, Visser was named the first female recipient of the [[Pete Rozelle Radio-Television Award]] by the [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]]. That same month, she was honored by the [[American Women in Radio and Television]] as the first woman sportscaster recipient of a Gracie Allen Award which celebrates programming created for women, by women and about women, as well as individuals who have made exemplary contributions to the industry. In 2007, she became the first woman sportscaster to host the Gracie Awards. Visser also, in 2007, received the Emily Couric Leadership Award—previously given to [[Sandra Day O'Connor]], [[Caroline Kennedy]] and [[Donna Brazile]]—and in 2007, she was honored at the 22nd Annual Sports Legend Dinner, along with Magic Johnson, Gary Player and John Elway to benefit the Buoniconti fund to cure paralysis. In 2005 she won the Pop Warner female achievement award and was inducted into the New England Sports Museum Hall of Fame, along with Boston Celtics legend [[Bob Cousy]] and the [[Miracle on Ice|1980 United States Olympic Hockey team]].

Visser has been honored with the Compass Award for "changing the paradigm of her business" and was one of the 100 luminaries commemorating the 75th anniversary of the CBS Television Network in 2003. She was named "WISE Woman of the Year" in 2002 and voted the "Outstanding Women's Sportswriter in America" in 1983 and won the "[[Women's Sports Foundation|Women's Sports Foundation Award]] for Journalism" in 1992. In 1999 she won the first AWSM Pioneer Award. Visser earned her bachelor's degree in English from [[Boston College]] and received an honorary doctorate of Journalism from her alma mater in May 2007.

Visser became the first woman sportscaster to carry the [[Olympic Torch]] when she was honored in 2004 by the International Olympic Committee as a "pioneer and standard-bearer." Visser worked her 31st ''Final Four''/[[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA Men's Basketball Championship]] this April 2009, having worked the tournament for the [[Boston Globe]], [[College Basketball on ESPN|ESPN]] and [[College Basketball on CBS|CBS Sports]]. This past season marked her 34th year covering the NFL and for covering the NFL.

In 2005, Visser was elected to the Museum of Television and Radio. [[Sean McManus (television executive)|Sean McManus]], President of CBS News and CBS Sports, summed up her contributions this way: "Lesley Visser's career has broken many barriers and defined previously unimagined roles for women in professional sports and sports broadcasting."

On June 8, 2015, Visser was inducted in the [[NSSA Hall of Fame]], along with [[Bill Raftery]], [[Hal McCoy]] and the late [[Dick Schaap]]. She is the third woman to be accorded this honor since the National Sportscasters and Sportswriters Association began presenting it in 1962.

Ep10: Katalin Zamiar (Kitana/Mileena) Part 1|date=6 September 2012|website=Youtube.com|accessdate=25 June 2016|via=YouTube}} [[martial artist]], [[Sports journalism|sportswriter]], fitness instructor, and martial arts actress. ==Biography== ===Life and career=== Katalin Zamiar holds a degree in [[anthropology]] from the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]], where she became a [[forensic science]] teacher. She has studied martial arts since 1982 and is an accomplished [[martial artist]] holding [[Black belt (martial arts)|black belt]]s in kung-fu, [[taekwondo]], [[Gōjū-ryū]] [[karate]] and [[Shōrin-ryū]] karate. She has owned POW! Mixed Martial Arts{{cite web|url=http://www.powkickboxing.com |title=POW! Mixed Martial Arts |publisher=Powkickboxing.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-08}} and Chicago Krav Maga{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagokravmaga.com/ |title=Chicago Krav Maga |publisher=Chicago Krav Maga |date= |accessdate=2013-09-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/20130602071315/http://chicagokravmaga.com:80/ |archivedate=June 2, 2013 }} training centers since 2001. Along with teaching at her training center in downtown Chicago, she has often covered the [[Ultimate Fighting Championship|UFC]] for ''Grappling'' magazine, focusing primarily on features and interviews. She has published more than 150 articles in various martial arts magazines including ''[[Black Belt Magazine|Black Belt]]'' and ''[[Inside Kung Fu]]'', and has been featured in magazines sch as ''[[Shape Magazine|Shape]]'', ''[[Allure (magazine)|Allure]]'' and ''[[Self (magazine)|Self]]''. She has worked as an international fitness and martial arts presenter and has spent some time as a spokesperson for the MMA gear firm Revgear. She has also written conditioning materials and manuals and can be seen in more than a dozen of [[Physical exercise|workout]] fitness/martial arts videos. Her other endeavors have included a summer training camp for upcoming basketball players and a non-profit charity MAKE.{{cite web|url=http://www.katalinusa.com/bio.asp |title=Katalin's Bio |publisher=Katalinusa.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-08 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508062346/http://www.katalinusa.com/bio.asp |archivedate=2014-05-08}} In 2014, she wrote the book ''Weight Training for Martial Arts''.{{cite web|author=Katalin Rodriguez-Ogren (Author) |url=http://www.amazon.com/Weight-Training-Martial-Arts-Ultimate/dp/1932549714/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1396329633&sr=1-1 |title=Weight Training for Martial Arts: The Ultimate Guide: Katalin Rodriguez-Ogren: 9781932549713: Amazon.com: Books |publisher=Amazon.com |date=2014-04-01 |accessdate=2014-05-07}} ===Acting=== Zamiar remains best known for her characterizations of the three female ninja characters [[Kitana]], [[Mileena]], and [[Jade (Mortal Kombat)|Jade]] in the 1993 fighting video game ''[[Mortal Kombat II]]''{{cite web|author=Katalin Rodriguez Ogren |url=http://www.chicagonow.com/blogs/pow-mixed-martial-arts/2010/10/i-am-the-original-kitana-meleena-and-jade-but-it-wont-be-my-halloween-costume.html |title=Video Gamer News: Mortal Kombat's Kitana - POW! Mixed Martial Arts |publisher=Chicagonow.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-08}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZTHI5hLaBC8|title=Mortal Kombat On The Spot: Katalin Zamiar (Kitana, Mileena and Jade) [HD]|date=1 May 2015|website=Youtube.com|accessdate=25 June 2016|via=YouTube}} (her video shoot costume was Kitana's blue; [[John Tobias]] created Mileena and Jade by altering the character colors to purple and green). In 1997, Zamiar, together with Philip Ahn ([[Shang Tsung]] in ''MKII'') and [[Elizabeth Malecki]] ([[Sonya Blade|Sonya]] in ''[[Mortal Kombat]]''), filed a lawsuit against [[Midway Games]] for royalties for the home ports of the game, a case in which Midway emerged victorious.{{cite web | url=http://www.ipcounselors.com/19970616.htm#a2 | title=Mortal Kombatants killed in kourt | date=1997-06-16 | publisher=IP Councillors |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071006175511/http://www.ipcounselors.com/19970616.htm#a2 |archivedate = 2007-10-06}}{{cite web|url=http://cyber.law.harvard.edu/metaschool/fisher/joint/links/cases/ahn.html|title=ahn.html|website=Cyber.law.harvard.edu|accessdate=25 June 2016}} In 1995, she and fellow ''Mortal Kombat'' actors [[Ho Sung Pak]] ([[Liu Kang]] in ''MKII'' and her boyfriend at the time[http://www.huguesjohnson.com/scans/mk2-behind-scenes/13-katalin-zamiar.jpg Mortal Kombat II Behind the Scenes], ''Video Games'', April 1994.), [[Daniel Pesina]], and Phillip Ahn appeared in ''[[Thea Realm Fighters]]'', a never-released fighting game produced exclusively for the [[Atari Jaguar]], as well having been in the also unreleased game ''Chi Yong'' that was planned for the [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] in 1994.{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/secretservicemagazine-1996-10/SecretService_10_1996#page/n84/mode/1up/ |title=Secret Service Magazine (October 1996) |publisher=Archive.org |date= |accessdate=2014-05-07}} In 1996, she portrayed a Jade-like ninja woman character named Chae Lee in the fighting game ''[[Catfight (video game)|Catfight]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.mobygames.com/game/windows/catfight-the-ultimate-female-fighting-game/cover-art/gameCoverId,197284/ |title=CatFight: The Ultimate Female Fighting Game - Windows Cover Art |publisher=Mobygames.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-07}}{{cite web|url=http://watchmojo.com/video/id/14159/|title=Top 10 Worst Fighting Games|website=Watchmojo.com|accessdate=25 June 2016}} In 2003, she played a minor part in the low-budget martial arts film ''Book of Swords''; in a cameo nod to her ''Mortal Kombat'' alter egos, Katalin once again portrayed a female ninja character, dressed in similar clothing as her ''MKII'' counterparts and even wielding two [[Sai (weapon)|sai]] as Mileena does (the movie also starred Pesina, Pak, and another ''Mortal Kombat'' actor, [[Richard Divizio]],{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.es/articles/2011-10-27-que-fue-de-los-actores-de-mortal-kombat-articulo|title=¿Que fue de los actores de Mortal Kombat?|website=Eurogamer.es|accessdate=25 June 2016}} all of whom are seen in ''MK''-style clothing/roles throughout the movie).{{cite web|url=http://www.fareastfilms.com/reviewsPage/Book-Of-Swords-2326.htm |title=Far East Films -
